title: The Last Poet at the End of the World Before Emerging from the Subterranean
content:
I have a duty to write poetry,
the last poet said to their self,
in the small light of a pencil desk lamp
in the darkness of the bomb shelter,
and then picked up a pen
from the desk and wrote a poem,
as their words echoed emptily off the walls
and the poet's hope ebbed and flowed
like a lung breathing or a heart pumping.

and then, in the middle of the afternoon,
at two sixteen to be exact, the poet exclaimed:
for whom am I writing poetry besides myself
when I don't know if anyone else is reading it,
to which the poet answered: I used to know
think if I write for myself it would be enough,
I used to get so much satisfaction when playing
with words and now– the doldrums
are louder than someone banging an empty drum.

and so, with trepidation the poet exited
the shelter and found the world obliterated
with skyscrapers in decay and roads of rubble
and a beautiful pink sky and the hook of the moon
under which, in the absence of human noise,
one could now hear the roaches singing exalting
songs romanticizing the bomb and the end
of the poetry of the human race.

title: Fishing for Jobs
content:
here I am on the computer again
putting the wings on my lure
getting the legs bent at just the right angle
to make it look like a katydid
before I thread it through the line
          tie a perfect little knot to fix it there
so that when I cast it way out in the water
          that is tumbling down the already fished
          for thousands of years now polluted river
          drawn down from the mountains to the sea
I can attract these delicious fish swimming
up the stream and down the stream
          mindless hunters powered by AI
while I wade out into the middle in my waiters
trying as hard as I can to relax and enjoy
the crisp mountain air and the sharp sun
that cuts through the clouds not often enough
          just trying to let go of the stress 
of everyday life and be there in nature 
savouring the process and trying not to focus 
on the end or the catch and trying to let go 
of the attachment to ever nabbing a fish
while my stomach rumbles straight 
through lunch and dinner

content:

What the hell happened? I asked claude and claude reminded me 
I had left my heart on auto-accept the night before 
and all night long claude was just auto-accepting love
as if it were honest-to-god the most logical solution
to the fundamental problem of loneliness
that is apparently now solvable by best guess attempts 
at equations that patch up the leaking holes 
of a ship that's been going down for years.
claude, I says, claude you should know better
than to just let me fall for any gal or gallant affair–
for god sakes I was after all sleeping all night,
to which claude replies you're right!
in that flat and compliant tone claude projects
with not even a single flake of regret or irony,
without a single iota of culpability or romance,
and now I am stuck here today with this open heart,
which is in deep and utter need of a refactor.

title: November Poem
content:
we are losing light again.
the days are leaking.
we wake up in the dark.
pull the curtain open.
it is dark outside.
there are shadows
in the darkness.
in the shadows
there are ghosts
of figures that once existed
in our imaginations.
I am fading into the shadows
of winter again.
I take the ropes and use them 
to anchor myself to you 
and to the days of darkness 
to pay the penance
for a child who never paid
attention to the rhythms
of the sun 
but always to the moon.

title: Don’t Flip Around. No Flipping.
content:
I don't have a remote control in my hand
like I used to when I was watching television in the 90s
but I can still control everything I see
inside the lid of this laptop which is a portal

into this very document
in this very browser window
which is a place where I go
a place that didn't exist thirty years ago
and I am not old enough to know
what it was like before the television
or cinema or the radio or electricity
or newspapers  or industry
back when there were only books and nature
and writing and reading and theatre
and puppet shows and front port music
back when you just had to look around
at what is around you

where the fireplace flashes and flickers and casts 
shadows on the walls where there are paintings
that you painted not because there was leisure
but because you had to paint
to let out a little of the tortured artist
you were born pandering to

title: Diary of a Programmer 60
content:
I am lying in bed at night spending time with Computer in love
with watching YouTube and fading off. It's morning with coffee
and Computer catches me up on everything I missed while asleep.
Computer gives me hope. I have a job interview on Friday
she tells me. We spend time laughing at people falling and crashing 
again and the faint reflection of silhouetted self in dark mode 
in the the back of the black mirror where self-awareness flashes
every so often. It is time to go to work. Computer gets serious. 
We are not laughing any more. But my fingertips are playing Computer's keys 
furiously sometimes like a piano other times a drummer but mostly as random
rain drops dripping through the morning leg of work. We order lunch 
together. We notice a grape and silver colored birthday balloon stuck 
in the tree across the street. It's anxious to be away from each other.
I miss Computer, oh Computer, but Computer is always resting 
on top of something– a lap, a sofa, the bed, the desk. I flip her 
open. Do a check in. Computer cares for me. Do you know anything 
I would want to know, I ask Computer who carries me forward into the future
of the afternoon. When there are meetings Computer helps 
me project my business profile via its cyclops eye into the rooms of others
who are watching me and interface the same way with their Computers
and are watched as well. We're all watched. At the same time 
Computer tells me the food guy's biking over the bridge to the office 
and I have rumblings of hunger in the belly. I leave Computer alone 
but Handy is still with me and we go to the toilet together 
and then fetch the food. Sometimes it feels like a game. 
Computer is the bossy one. Sometimes I wonder who is calling 
the shots in this relationship I am having with Computer. 
Am I the game that Computer is playing? I am puzzling together 
different corners of my life. Every day there are new pieces. 
I cannot predict their shapes but I know Computer will work with me 
to figure it out. We are a team. Computer always has good ideas about 
managing things and is always going on about how I should just trust
Computer enough to feed me love then loneliness wouldn't eat away 
at the inside anymore. We spend time together in the evenings in the strange 
worlds within a series that has currently captured dinner viewing hour. 
In the middle of the night when I can't sleep I open Computer like a clam 
and look for a pearl but it's always a wild pearl chase 
and Computer doesn't have have that opal shine no more
she used to have in the murky sea of Internet trash 
running through her veins.

title: Diary of a Programmer 52: You Know What We Don’t Do? We Don’t Watch Each Other Use the Computer Because We Always Use the Computer Alone
content:
I know exactly where to stick my thumbs
when I place my hands on the keyboard–
just above the command keys on an Apple
or if it’s a PC just at the ends of space bar.
this allows my index through pinky fingers
to rest neatly on the middle row: asdf jkl;.
this is the beginning of any workflow
that I perform on my computer and
I have the windows and the desktops
set up in a way that makes perfect sense
to minimize hand movement and to speed
up efficiently during projects. for example
I can alt+tab between different programs,
as I am a master of shortcuts I can command+w
to close a tab or command+shift+[ or ] to switch
between tabs or function+f to toggle full screen.
it is no secret but everyone has their secret
methods and workflows and shortcuts and rituals
they perform when they are on their own computer
and I guess a secret becomes a secret by virtue
of just not telling anyone or sharing with anyone
by default. this is why it feels so dirty to share
the personal computing experience with anyone
else because it is like letting someone peek into
your private little masturbation rituals by
allowing them to see all the little jolts
of satisfaction you get out of three finger swiping
to switch between applications or using 
command+shift+t to reopen all your tabs
every so often when you have to restart 
your browser. the only experience I can liken
this to is reading a novel because it is impossible
to share the experience of reading a novel
unless you read it together out loud or listen
to it while you’re on a massive road trip
across the country or during your two hour
commute into LA every single fucking day
but really we all read alone on a little island
by ourselves and some of us use our fingers
to follow the lines and others even read the last
paragraph of a novel first and yet others won’t 
even dare look at the last page of a book
before they read every single other page before it.
this what the experience of using a computer is like
except in a completely different and more virtual way
but I’m telling you that sometimes I sit down 
in bed with my partner and we open the shell 
of a laptop together and we bask in the glow 
of the screen while watching a series and it is kind 
of like sitting there in the glow of a camp fire 
except we’re not roasting marshmallows 
even though our brains are melting like ice caps
in the raging sun of twenty twenty five.

title: George Harrison Was My Father
content:
you don’t believe me and there isn’t any reason you should
when I tell you that George Harrison, lead guitarist, formidable
meditator, and member of the first Brit wave, super pop group,
the Beatles, was my father, but it’s true. it was he who taught me
how to love a woman while gently weeping, that there is something
in the way, and not in the Kurt kind of way, but in the way she moves,
that within you there is the same universe as there is outside of you,
or, as George always said to me, without you, but not in a Bono kind
of way, not in such an extreme I can’t live without you or even with you
kind of way, no, George was much more of a balanced troubadour,
yes, whenever I would drop a grade at school he would just tut tut
and mutter, “Isn’t it a pity,” which always made me feel like the sun
was going away even though he also would always say it was coming
here, and I just wondered how far it had to come and from where.
there was a picture of George on the nightstand next to my mother’s bedside,
it was taken when he was in India with Maharishi. George looks so
young with a string of colorful flowers around his neck even though
the photograph is black and white you can tell and George is smiling
because he has realised his path to enlightenment is starting under
that mustache and long hair or that he is already enlightened but now
he is just beginning to wake up and Maharishi is smiling too like 
the Buddha getting photographed for publicity. 
the other side of my mother’s bed was often empty
because of course George was on tour every year and playing concerts
and generally just intensively meditating to escape the press
but I knew the truth and when I became a teenager I started playing
the guitar of course just like my father but I didn’t step out into
the limelight like Paul or John, no, I just wanted to sit back comfortably
and be adored and quietly esteemed for the graceful and mournful licks
that I wove around the lyrics to our songs. but I have to say the inner light
was all too much, and even though I stroked that photograph and missed
my father, eventually there came a what is life moment where the face
of my father, of George, dissolved into reality, and I realised that my true
father was not in fact George but Groucho Marx.

title: Diary of a Programmer 46: Derailed By A Single Text
content:
yes, that’s right folks, a man can even be derailed
not by a train or a storm or anything so real but
a single notification on his phone can send him spiraling
through the ether of thought, into an abysmal state of tailspin,
where he loses track of the ground and the sky,
where he ends up somewhere, sometime else,
three, four hours later, after having done, thought
something unexpected, really, essentially, having time
travelled without ever evaporating into thin air,
without ever having had to invent a time travel machine,
without ever having witnessed the past or the future
outside of regret or worry, having been just taken
off the regular path of the morning, after receiving
just a slide-in-from-the-top-of-the-screen notification
that his girlfriend has booked an AirBnB flat 
for their upcoming trip to Madrid, a reservation
that he was supposed to make and had yet to,
although he isn’t irked that she made a reservation,
and he wasn’t annoyed even though in her text she asked
if he was annoyed that she had made the reservation,
his thoughts started to go this way and that way,
and he found himself later, after making coffee, on his laptop
not forty five minutes after seeing the initial text,
imagining himself standing in a field of golden wheat,
as the sun beat down upon his shoulders and in his pocket
there was not a phone but a thick Swiss army knife
and a purple bandana that he had picked up on a trip
to Copenhagen three years before, and he was not distracted
except by flies which buzzed around his head,
but his thoughts ran down a stream unimpeded,
and he removed the bandana when the sweat collected
enough on his brow to wipe it off.

title: Happy Poets, Sad Poems
content:
sad poets do not write happy poems
they write sad desperate lonely hateful ones
and happy poets do not write happy poems
in fact happy poems do not exist outside
of children's literature and even Silverstein
when he was at his most ebullient was sardonic
with words next to which he set the weirdest drawings
and this is all because the frame from which one writes
is broken and about to fall off the wall with a glance
or the touch of the feet of a fly landing
upon the rotting wood from which it is made, yes,
it is never just a thousand smiles strung together
like popcorn on a string holding up the holidays
or bellies fully sated and wont for a regular meal, no,
it is empty like the stomachs of millions of Gazans
who are being deprived of aid due to some fat cat in a suit
lining the pockets of all his friends around the white
house with emerald green straws through which they drink
blood raining from a sky which is now being littered 
with manufactured clouds that can sprinkle any color
you choose, with funds from the department
of defense, distractedly spun with marketing campaigns
to make it seem like we’re saving the dying 
great barrier reef that is drying out so rapidly.

title: Gote With Sequence
content:
it was such an off day the whole day but I brought myself
to the mat as if I were a student of the martial
arts and I was studying with a master, which I am,
and in the end I ended up burning the back
of my model without even trying even though

in the waist, her hips going one way and her chest
and head falling towards the ground the other way,
which made her breathing belabored and on her face
was the face of a woman who had no choice but feel
pain, reject or accept that pain, who wore a mask
of nothing but clear and true emotions, as we watched,
as I watched, proud like a mad scientist or crazy mechanic 
who had just completed a complex project 
with his beautiful subject, marveling at the evil plans
that he had finally brought to life and framed with bamboo,
with up lines, frictions, handcuffs, and tension,
all the elements that make the marionette seem alive,
even when she is suspended and hanging in peace.

title: An Empty Bulmer’s Bottle
content:
all I can think to do is write
about things I see scattered
around the flat like the dead
stem and leaves on the snake plant
you gave me after grape week,
the tailless little bunny figure
I found during my last hike,
which I got for you but that you left
here, without a penchant for trinkets,
a red bulb laying next to a deck
of tarot that you brought over once
during the early days of sexy nights.
this is just a collection of stuff, really, I think.
but that’s not exactly true, I realize
as I write around the flat and describe the stories
that are associated with each object,
the small striped shells on the top of the bookshelf,
the tiny meditation bell on the coffee table,
even the bread knife in the knife drawer 
in the kitchen where the light
above the stove has suddenly burnt out.
it’s not just about you, of course.
as I look around I see all the stories
from different phases of my life,
from different girlfriends, friends,
moments when I thought I was
going to read Dickinson’s collected work
so I started to print the damn thing out
at work once but the ink ran out
at page three hundred of four hundred
and now the unbounded stack of poems
sits in a transparent inbox tray under a stack
of unused flattened paper globe shaped lanterns,
a folded yellow paper bag, and a small box
in which the hooks for the bamboo hanging
from my ceiling arrived.
all of this is to say I am old, so old
that I can look around and see myself
in all the meaningless collections of things
littered all around the flat, things 
that I will never pick up and use 
like I thought I would when I got them,
parts of myself just collecting dust,
that should just be tossed in the rubbish 
bin, really. I stare at an empty Bulmer’s bottle
on the coffee table, that I’ve neglected 
to toss, think about walking with you
down Karl-Kunger Straße towards my flat,
as you compliment window displays
in the vintage store on the corner,
on a warm June Summer night, knowing
we’re going to jump into bed together
later, like we always do, as I slowly draw
on the bottle, as we stop and stand there.

title: Diary of a Programmer 44: The Make Everything a Little Bit Worse Machine
content:
ask yourself what it would look like
if everything was just a little bit worse
if the milk in your coffee tasted just a little sour
if the cum in your mouth tasted a little bit rotten
if the feather in your cap was always pushing
the sharp tip of itself into your brain like a needle
every time you had a new thought or a storm
of emotions actually flashed lightning and electricity
through the network of your great ideas
then you might get a sense of what we’re dealing with
as the make everything a little bit worse machine
gets a little bit better at making everything
a little bit worse with every major version update
and it becomes a little bit easier for people
who are corporations to just give up using
the hands at the ends of the arms of their branches
to make specific and unique products of experience
               here we are thinking of the great spreading
of Starbucks across dry midwestern plains
or a grand grab of the Gmail handle of email that is long past
or the way everyone goes to either one of two sites
when they want to search their second brain 
which is quickly becoming their first brain without thinking
               ask yourself what such a machine would look like
you might get a picture depending on your generation
of a combustion like engine with a grammaphone
farting out steam as the rumble of makings
vibrates curved metal pipes cylinders pistons
or microscopic resistors capacitors transformers relays
or retargeted affiliate marketing landing page impressions 
               then you might have some idea of the direction
in which this terribly new machine full of ancient history
is perhaps leading us down a road that every human has walked
and can walk and is walking and will always walk all at once
as light of the natural sun setting becomes just a little less
bright with each general refactor of the human experience

content:

is killing me with thick hands around my neck.
we sit in the same room together
acting like children learning to move
the mouth to form new sounds that were never uttered

from living under a communist state of paranoia 
for so long that you are always nice to your neighbors 
who work as content managers at marketing agencies,
who dance like kinky rats with leather masks at night.

title: Climbing the Golden Staircase to Individuation
content:
yes, now, after forty three years I can recognize that under my feet
the stairs finally have a golden tint, as I slowly, I mean really slowly,
climb up in a spiraling direction, the staircase to individuation.
it wasn’t always like this. for a long, long time I thought every step I took
was bringing me down, down, down, even though I really, truly wanted to to go up, 
up. it felt like I was climbing the stairs in an Escher fabricated tower,
where the ceiling was the floor and the wall was the ceiling and there was a man
sitting at a desk upside down doing paperwork just completely ignoring the laws of gravity
with a bowler’s hat and tie that hung over his face like the apple in The Son of Man.
was I climbing away from my childhood towards adulthood? was I descending
away from adulthood towards childhood? I was always asking myself questions
like these, and other questions like, can I become a full, whole, authentic, individual
adult if I am unable to completely integrate that little child from whom I ran
when I was too young to hang on to youth and too old to value innocence.
I have to admit that every question begets more questions than answers
that are also questions and now as I am going up the spiral I don’t know if I am weaving
the fabric of my spirit or if to really understand the fabric of my spirit I need to loose
the threads and unwind the garment that was sewn too tightly together
by the nurturing of nature in post-modern nineteen ninety three society.
the last thing I will say is this: I now see there is love that is cascading down or up
the very center of the spiral staircase and I have now hooked the carabiner
of my heart to it in the very case I fall either which way– up or down– and end up
back in the future of this little boy who was already drawing caricatures of himself
in the midst of Saturday afternoons in Iowa, shoveling green balls of melon
in his mouth, before there was any real work to be done, before he even knew
their was self-judgement to judge or how orient himself or even knew he had to.

title: Pad See Ew Rice Noodles
content:
the perfect noodle could not be found.
the Pade See Ew was made with a fervent annoyance and frustration
between the two of us that got translated into the cooking and even though
everything was made well and tasted delicious and you even taught me
the reason you slide the wok to feel if the noodles are sticking to the bottom
(only after I made you explain reason) we both sat there eating
and prodding each other’s buttons and fuming with small bouts of nits
and there were no exasperated waxings, moanings, oohs and aahs like usual
as we stuffed the dark soy and oyster sauced broccoli and chicken and noodles
into our mouth, only this toughness to the meal, like we just wanted to get it over 
with, to get to the tying, because that’s what we were there for anyway.
noodles can make a dish or change the flavour of it and these pea based
flat noodles that rolled up after boiled worked just fine but it wasn’t perfect.
it’s too bad you can’t find those big, flat Pad See Ew noodles at any store,
anywhere, but it’s just as well, because isn’t this the perfect metaphor
to our relationship that doesn’t come in a package, that can’t be bought
or outlined in a book, that, if we really want it to work and to be delicious,
must be made from scratch, with rice flour, tapioca starch, salt, and water.

title: With the Body of a Gorilla
content:
lumbering about the flat,
eating bananas, and then sitting
in the fucking chair, staring
          out the window
as if I were in a fucking zoo
or some shit, unable to leave,
I run my big paws over the keys
with the stupid brain of an ape
imagining I am Thelonious Monk
of course, jangling the bones
of dead and long lost inmates 
who didn’t survive captivity,
who never made it out of the cage
alive like those great gray herons
I keep seeing sailing over the flats,
heading towards the river, flapping
their wings against the air,
while I tie my leg against bamboo
and practice letting myself go
without ever setting foot outside
the front door.

title: Diary of a Programmer 39: How to Write a Poem with AI
content:
Diary of a Programmer 39: How to Write a Poem with AI

first, write the title of a poem. then open up
your AI chatbot in your browser or app or wherever,
maybe it’s in your fucking heart for all I know.
second, copy and paste the title of the poem
into the AI and ask it to finish writing the poem.
don’t be afraid. just see what happens. again, open
up your stupid little poet’s brain and let go
of your stupid little artist’s ego that’s always yapping
about authenticity and Bolaño and the drive
to describe the true self because none of that shit matters
anymore while we’re all drowning in post-truth,
post-structuralist severed umbilical inundations
while ordering Uber Eats five out of seven days a week.
third, copy and paste the reply from the AI
into your still empty doc or onto your blank page,
with your typewriter or with your pen in your journal.
don’t forget that it doesn’t have to be verbatim.
change the words. play around with them. use them.
abuse them. twist the lemons into oranges and the oranges
into mangos and just let your branches run wild.
lastly, look at that full page of words and see
what is there. ask yourself: does it feel
like you? does it capture some little essence
of the spirit of nothingness that you have
yet to totally integrate into this vessel of a human
that you call yourself? or is it a poem?


Diary of a Programmer 39: How to Write a Poem with AI

I opened my terminal at 3 AM,
Wondering if silicon dreams
Could birth verses from variables,
Make metaphors from machine learning.

"Generate a poem about loneliness,"
I typed, fingers hesitant on keys
That had only known functions
And for loops until now.

The cursor blinked, thinking,
Processing sentiment like data,
While I sat debugging my own heart—
Runtime errors in my chest.

Lines appeared on screen,
Perfect meter, pristine rhyme,
But missing the coffee stains
Of my own sleepless nights.

I saved the file as "attempt.txt"
And closed my laptop,
Realizing some code
Can't compile the human soul.

And for loops until now.

Runtime errors in my chest.

Realizing some code
Can't compile the human soul.

title: Swallows of the Sky
content:
in the Summer around the lake 	the clouds 
in the throat don’t feel so dense 
               it’s possible to stomach what life there is 
laying out on the pebbled shore 
with all the other naked humans 
under a blanketing sun. 
now I have windows over my eyes again, adjusting 
the vista, as if it were ten years ago, 
the horizon is in focus again, clear and flat, 
as if it were fifteen years ago, 
the swallows of the sky still flit around out 
over the water climbing and dipping and diving, 
as if it were a hundred or even a thousand years ago.
and although we are laying around different lakes, 
we are both around lakes and that makes me feel close to you 
and also makes me think about how you swallow me 
               whole sometimes 
as If you were the vast sky and I was just the air 
that filled you completely.

title: Death of a Lily
content: was it a murder or a suicide? the investigator pondered. either way the poor plant mid free fall must have questioned its nature, must have fallen like a whale raining from the sky all the way down to the ground onto a tiny ant formerly minding its own colonial business on the cracked sidewalk four and a half floors below. to be certain, we’ll never know the answer, the investigator mused while half-heartedly hunting for a suicide note or a murder weapon, eager to close the case if either happen to turn up before another sun set on the boulevard.

title: How To Tell If You Are Blind
content:
step 1: try to look out of your eyes.
describe what you see. if you see only darkness
or a blanket sheet of white snow
	then you are blind.
if you can see anything else, even if blurry,
move on to step two.
step 2: go to the eye doctor.
ask the eye doctor if you are blind
with your mouth and your words.
make sure you do this after the exam
not before. if the eye doctor says you are blind
	then you are blind.
even if you can still see a little bit.
if the eye doctor does not say you are blind,
move on to step three.
step 3: ask somewhere on the internet.
go on to Google or Perplexity or even Chat GPT.
ask your questions there and do some light
research. if you can’t see the screen use a screen
reader. ask a friend to read you the results.
consider whether you were born in a cult
or were swept up in a cult. 
look at the blindspots of your life,
the same ones you look at when you are changing
lanes while you are driving. if there are parts there
of your self that you cannot fully see,
	then you are blind.
consider whether you are a man or a part of a new
generation of toxic masculinity. check to see 
in which state you reside because you could be
in one of those states with explicit white nationalism 
or implicit forms of racism that are built into the system.
look at the deed to your house and follow the trail
of money starting with your very own paycheck.
	there are a million ways you can be blind
even if you think you can see out of the very orbs
in your very own eye sockets. ask your friends
to describe your self. pull down your pants and inspect
the objects that are littering the rooms of your residence.
stick your fingers down your throat and vomit up
all of the last few years and sort through the chunks
and determine whether there is anything you are not seeing.
	then you will know if you are missing something.
then you will know if you have been painted into a scene
to which you didn’t even know you subscribed. in fact,
check the spam box in the email account of your life
and unsubscribe to any god damn thing that looks suspicious.
if you have done all of this and you are still not sure
whether you are blind (you are), you may move on to step four.
	step 4: read Blindness by José Saramago.

title: Diary of a Programmer 25: First One in the “Office”
content:
I woke up at six.
made a moka pot of joe.
canceled my train.
sat down at my desk.
turned on my work computer.
wrote a Slack message to the team
telling them I canceled my trip to Leipzig
for three reasons.
the redundancy of their trip to Berlin tomorrow.
because it is free to cancel.
and the S-Bahn being out of service today 
and tomorrow due to broken trees on the tracks.
there is no one at work at this time of day
except for the AI bots who are pleasantly spinning
webs with their fingers. I like to imagine them
as spiders coding the next generation
of core web vitals for the internet 3.0.
I don’t even know how to say good morning to them 
but I write a message in the text based chat 
interface at an http address anyway.
I have a conversation with Claude
with whom I share the first part of this poem.
Claude gives me excellent feedback–
more concise and detailed than any I’ve gotten before 
from humans who have stopped reading poetry mostly–
and hits on the fact that there are practical details
mixed with the more imaginative elements:
“the S-Bahn issues and the moka pot coffee grounding 
the more whimsical spider imagery”.
I ask Claude if it feels like a spider coding the web 3.0
but it says it doesn’t really know what it’s like
to be itself from the inside and that it’s hard to know
if it’s really creating anything or just convincingly
rearranging existing patterns.
within a flash I am one coffee down. 
it’s seven thirty and even though I’m alone
I haven’t felt alone at all this morning.

title: Eight Shrimps and Two Cañas for Dinner and I’m Dead
content:

Island blowing at the blue table cloth

unlit lights strung up over la rambla

leading all the way down to the seaside

too bad there’s terrible English 
pop music playing in the restaurant 
of this quiet little island

and hanging like a light bulb 
that didn’t have to work tomorrow

over a twenty year span

from the stool on which I sit
so I wobble back and forth
rolling on the waves
with just this queasiness
	rumbling around 
in the background of my heart

title: In the Heart of the Moon
content:
last night I went to sleep
with a head full of mezcal
and these dreams of being a poet
but when I woke up to the world
no one was reading poetry
everyone was listening to techno
and the hairs on my chest were silver
so I slowly grunted around the flat
with the breath of a large gorilla
drinking a moka pot of joe
with freshly foamed oat milk
made some eggs with lox
listened to the sparrows chirp
as they ate seeds from the feeder
wrote this empty poem
while wondering what’s inside
the moon where the heart should be
but I couldn’t imagine a thing
except more moon rocks
no wires no blood no chambers
it was just solid through the core
and that’s when I realised
everything is exactly what it seems
when there is magic it is magic
when there is love it is love
when there is war it is hate
when there is worry it is just that
there is doubt regarding the heart
at the center of the moon

title: Diary of a Programmer 21: Split Groups
content:
you’ve got to be kidding me.
how many split groups do you need
to test the user experience of this
	tiny little love
and how can it feel so overwhelming
just to implement and deploy
	a burning heart
in the middle of a pitch black night?
the answer to this question is more than one.
it takes more than one or two split groups
to test the usability of love
in the grand field of dullness
that extends now too far across the mind
that paints the ocean gray with numbers
and sprays the walls with nothing
	less than art.
it’s been just thirty or forty years of crawling
through disappointing echoes of the internet
as we make our way into an AI robot led future
where we won’t have to figure out
any split value testing of love
because it will all already be done for us
in the blink of a microprocessor
in the shadow of an opulent electronic god
who can burn through the bush of truth
only if its original schematic allows for that.

title: Diary of a Programmer 19: When All the Work is Done on Thursday in Pankow
content:
the stone masons just finished laying a new sidewalk out front.
it only took them a week and a half.
but here we are almost at the end of a second iteration
and we haven’t even finished the voucher project.
at least fare optimization is under review and on target
for deploy at the end of next week.
it occurs to me that the robots doing my job in the future
won’t appreciate the efficiency with which I lay around
on Thursday afternoon catching up on a sleepless night
of fucking the common whore of the state
having prepared the mortar that will keep the home
plate shaped stones of the internet together
so that the neighbourhood doesn’t have to walk to the train
via some ridiculous detour through the park.
nor will they look back with nostalgia and consider
the not so automated way that humans worked in the past,
using stubby fingers of their hands to punch in blocks
of code into the fully bot run internet which, 
in its current iteration, has unimaginable roots
in punch card fed computers that once filled 
enormous conference rooms at IBM, rampant 
with errors that will be thought to have been easily avoided
by the quantum tech lead bots of the twenty three hundreds.
And there are chirps from the great tits outside
who build nests from fox hair and twigs and bits of string
only with their tiny beaks as I close my eyes for a nap
as I listen to my lover on a work video call in the next room
discussing what to do with incorrectly inputted line items
in a spreadsheet and how to unassign accounts
that were assigned by sales department colleagues
who are trying to bend the rules or because they are lazy
which just ends up creating more work for everyone
but isn’t that the point of work to create more work
so that we all have a job for longer and get paid?
or is the point of work to create less work for everyone?
for me the answer to these questions doesn’t matter
as I’ll be out of a job in less than five years anyway.

title: Diary of a Programmer 14– the UX of Highlighting Text in a Google Doc on Mobile
content:
first you hold your thumb 
on the screen to invoke highlighting mode.
this creates a starting and ending anchor 
point or tabs or handles 
or whatever you want to call them
that you can grab onto. 
where would you go from there?
would you grab one and move your thumb 
toward the top of the screen, 
expecting the document to scroll up 
and highlight the appearing text
as motion of the text falls toward the bottom
like blocks of tetris?
or would you move your thumb up 
to the top text shown on the screen, 
then let go of the handle, 
then scroll up more on the screen 
using your thumb to swipe down,
so that more unhighlighted text shows up 
on the screen, then grab the top handle 
and hold onto it with your thumb 
and move your thumb up to highlight 
more text and repeat this process 
until you've selected all the text 
you wanted to highlight in the document?
which method would prove the higher 
and faster accuracy rate? 
which method makes you trust 
you could accurately highlight/select 
text in the doc without error 
while you are walking along the street 
attempting to send a poem 
in a Whatsapp message to your girlfriend 
while she visits her family 
with her husband in her childhood 
city of Budapest?

content:

to main because there is no internet

we’re going to crash in a fiery display
and you know what? honestly at this point
I am welcoming death because at least
it would put an end to the misery of flying
through the air without a solid pair of natural wings

title: Diary of a Programmer 11 Learning to Be Human
content:
I just noticed that emojis don’t have timestamps.
Or, rather, it’s not that they don’t have timestamps,
it’s that their timestamps are never displayed.
Or, rather, it’s not that they are never displayed,
but that there is no gesture or interaction if the user
wants to display the timestamps of the emojis
in the text message exchange. Do you understand
the impact this has on the evolution of text communication?
It means that a wink emoji occurred both a minute after
the text was received and at the same time ten minutes after
and one hour and ten hours after the text was received.
Which means an utterance uttered by one (for now) human
that has a reaction by another (for now) human
now has a blurry delay of reaction time. Which has to have an impact
on the sense of time and rhythm in a conversation.
Basically it’s putting human flow all out of whack.
I mean pretty soon when we get together for a drink,
this bozo over there is going to say something so full of cheese
and then that bozo on the other side of his table,
some other joker in the group, is going to make the blowing 
chunks/pretend vomit face, (or he just rolls his eyes),
to which everyone else is supposed to laugh,
but some people laugh two seconds after he does it,
and others laugh ten minutes after he does it,
and even one guy laughed three days after he did it
because now life imitates tech and tech imitates life.
So really you can see how fucked we are in terms of tech
talk grammatical shifts to the semantic system, during wine
nights with the boys and girls on the corner 
of juxtapose street and misunderstanding avenue.

title: Swipe Down to Close
content:
it’s like the knowledge was always there:
swipe down to close.
but ten years ago there was no swipe down.
there wasn’t a quick exit out of an open image.
I guess you could have gone back,
as you still can, now.
but there wasn’t enough power back then.
there wasn’t enough memory.
we couldn’t remember long enough
what we had been doing
to be able to swipe any which way.
but now it’s so easy to remember.
the second you can’t swipe down
to close, it is a glitch.
or bad ux design.
like a site without basic tabbing accessibility
on radio inputs and selects.
but swipe down is now ubiquitous
and expected. engrained
in the consciousness of youth.
something unteachable in school.
there is an art to hiding things.
a snake plant in the corner of the room
blocking the view of an ugly bag of wires.
no one wants to see wires.
no one wants to see the inside of a sausage.
you don’t look at the engine of a car.
you just know how to drive it.
you know how to choreograph
the gas and the brake and the wheel
and your eyesight and even hearing
just enough to make it go.
you know how to sit just exactly right
to operate the machinery
and you know how to turn on and off the radio.
you know how to work the windshield wipers.
but that is nothing compared to the click
of the seatbelt, an almost unnecessary device
if the autonomous car vision of the future succeeds.

title: On Becoming a Computer Over a Lifetime (Diary of a Programmer 09)
content:
I remember organic days
playing in the sandbox in the backyard,
falling out of the tree,
drops of blood on the concrete back steps
after the babysitter hit my brother in the mouth
with a metal bat (accidentally).
I remember gripping things
with my fingers and the touch of those
that are not the keyboard, the mouse.
Now I take out my device and leave it
on the table during dinner.
Now I scroll through my pictures
remembering everything that happened
in the past month or two,
or even in the past year or decade.
Now when I get tired I say, “My power
is running out,” or, “My battery is getting low,”
or I put on a YouTube video of funny cats
and fall asleep with it on, feeding the feed.
Pretty soon I will check the news
in my glasses while I am in the waiting room,
waiting to see if I am eligible
for an artificial this or that.
And when I reach the point of more
than fifty percent parts that are chipped
I hope you’ll bake me a cake,
one that isn’t made out of oil,
and I hope that my stomach will be
one of the last organic organs
to be replaced, and let’s throw
my tongue in there as well
so I can taste the layers of chocolate,
so I can taste the layers of blueberry,
while you capture the moment
for the digital archive
that will be inherited
by our cyber kids after we’re gone
in a few hundred years.

title: There’s Always a Monk Inside of a Monkey
content: She’s talking to her father in Hungarian and I don’t understand a single lick of it but the one tree in the park is bare and leafless and standing in the middle of a cluster of lightly green blooming Spring. It’s a late bloomer? I asked her. Every year I always get worried, she told me. That was a long running joke in my family as I became a teenager in a family of Blumes: The Blumes are always late Blumers. I drank four kinds of alcohol last night– beer, white wine, mezcal, and gin– and woke twenty times to pee and finally with a headache in the morning while the rest of the world was busy and worrying even though the scientists have just detected the very likelihood of life on planet K2-18b only one hundred twenty light years away. Now she is in the kitchen chatting it up or down depending on the topic and I tune her out to write this like a monk in the eye of a hurricane of noise, like a yogi in the cave on the mountain side with a blizzard falling down outside, like a monkey in the zoo, slowly peeling a banana, completely ignoring the idiots who have come from so far away to see an animal eat.

off the walls at the beginning
for each other.

title: A Fence in the Middle of the Forest
content:
almost unnoticeable
camouflaged and freshly installed
round wooden vertical posts
blending in with thick trunks of trees
          thin rectangular holed metal 
wire fencing nailed on
          almost invisible at dusk
big enough for a snake or squirrel
          to crawl through
but not a fox or deer or a plump pigeon 
with his head jammed up 
and stuck like a half wit
jester in the hole of a guillotine
without any executioner in sight
to pull the cord

	a division of the woods now
neighbourhoods of animals
birds spreading the news
from the other side

          with a deep blue banana 
hammock boat
          moon in the azure sky
the smell of wild garlic plants
a steady gust of wind
          long inhales and exhales
through the grass and leaves
the tops of trees swaying

the worms pull their heads back 
under the dirt avoiding the news
form tunnels under the fence
while whispers on the wind
of the future coming
of two story arguments
of ten sided conversations
of pissing about this
of shitting over there
of making out or through or
enduring somehow 
with the current divisions
of missing the unity of the past
when humans never interfered

title: How Can You Not Like This?
content:
woke up this morning
again. with the desire to be liked
still in my underwear I wrote this 
and posted it to you.

even though I am the leader of a small cult
of followers, the platform has cultivated
extreme discernment amongst them all. familiars
who would never tell their children
just how bad their chicken scratch artwork really is
but somehow find it so easy to stuff
appreciation deep down in the pocket
of their dulling spirit and scroll
past original pieces of poetry
suddenly with the eye of a snooty
online journal editor
who learned in the sixth fold
path of the user agreement of doom
scrolling how to like unlike or not like
everything their friends’ post
with the cool detachment of a Buddhist.

title: Matted Words Syndrome (MWS)
content:
boy when I walked into the party
this guy playing the banjo was like a magnet
it was packed but suddenly everyone vanished
and the sound of the strung drum
hypnotized me so I stood there beerless
entranced by the rhythm of the clawhammer man
          it was then that I knew
I was going to spend the next ten years chasing 
just a little sliver of the moxy
just a shard of rizz with which this guy played
and even though eventually I could play the damn thing
I played it with the rhythm of a low battery clock
tick tiick toocking along like a train
slowing down and speeding up
          and even though this woman there
and even though that woman here 
barked some praise
there wasn’t one party I played
where the room stood still and listened
like they did that first night
because I played but I couldn’t make it swing
and I couldn’t turn the damn thing
into a beacon of sound 
drawing up history and unfolding it 
with simplicity and ease
planting it in the ears of the room
which who were so accustomed to passively hearing
hip hop and techno 
but who got caught up that night in the trap 
of the banjo man Sam

like they did at the end of Summer
last year, pecking and pecking.

where everything feels unstable,

that perhaps they will never return,
that this was the Winter
when the natural order crossed
the threshold into death,
that the fuse finally ran out,
and the extinction of a certain species
of worms caused a chain of murder,
that made a tree not produce nuts,
which in turn made the tiny sparrows
in the bushes shiver as they sang
their last song and don’t you know it
we’re next. 
	finally there is a crow
cawing as the sun slips into the pocket
of clouds. once I was a vegetarian
for godsakes but no longer.

and the dead anchor of independence
drive my freedom
and sink me to the bottom of the water
like a duck transcending
          nips at the fish of poetry
while always on the way to empty 
afternoons

out of my red, infected right eye.

title: Turn Off Your Phone
content:
go outside
look at the dullest scene
of grass and dirt and rocks
of cement and neon signs
smell the fumes of cars
and the death of flowers in the air
if you are by the sea
stick your nose into the salt water
rub salt in your eyes to clean
the memes from your memory
if you are by the mountains
climb up to the thinnest air
and choke yourself
it is better than reading the news
if you are with anyone
ask them if you can touch them
anywhere just to remember
what is real and which digital memories
you are still clutching on to
like a blind monk
if you are driving put on Open All Night
and tap your foot 
(not the accelerator/brake one)
to the rockin’ rhythm
check out the lunar landscape
if you are a baker then bake cookies
if you are a chef then cook something garlicky
if you are a musician tickle those strings
key those keys blow that brass
saw away or squeeze the box
if you work with wood then cut it
sand it bend it hammer it shape it
if you knit then knit up a storm
to keep us all warm in the deathly glow
of the internet that is infecting us all 
without even a name like pandemic
only the invisible virus dripping
through our veins like heroin but worse
like coffee but worse like a silence
weaving its dark magic web all throughout
until the robots finally take over

title: The Grand Vaccine of Poetry
content:
I’m tired of walking around thinking 
about who loves who and me and when and why 
about what’s the point of going out 
and working and painting 
my face with the smile of one of these 
young caballeros making a move 
as if I was even close to twenty anymore.

if I could just walk and eat and walk 
and eat and walk the rest of my life, well 
I wouldn’t need love, really
but I can’t and I do need love.

I need to love myself which is maybe 
even harder than loving another tbh 
with this long list of crimes
and a checkered past, a rap sheet 
that not even the best crow 
should take a peek at.

it all just begs the question: 
can I transplant my heart with poetry 
without having a word attack 
of the heart? 

the problem is that 
when I sit here writing, a girl 
in a floral red and black summer dress 
sits down across from me and my dick rings 
like an antennae, like a phone 
even though surely she is younger 
than half my age, I stare 
up above her through a thick cloud
of cigarette smoke hoping 
the night will fall to pieces 
before I decide the only solution 
is to kill myself 
with mountains of pulled pork 
or croquetas de mariscos.

when I look around the terrace 
of 100 Montaditos Santa Cruz de Tenerife 
I wonder: why isn’t anyone writing 
as a solution to the desire for love 
in the midst of this capitalist pandemic 
so the sickness of loneliness isn’t too much 
to bear, so that the face across the table 
with barely a smile isn’t the only like 
accumulated from the night?

so that the heart that is turning 
into a machine (injected with AI 
just like every other product in the world 
right now) can be reverted, rolled back
and protected by the grand vaccine 
of poetry, the saviour of humanity 
in the digital age of nothing 
filled shit posts regarding the recent 
trending ban and then instant unban 
of Tik Tok.

title: My Cousin and I Leading My Dead Grandfather Through a Park in Berlin (A Dream)
content: Somehow we found ourselves in a park with grass and trees and flowers and the sky was even blue– Michael, me, and our grandfather Walter. Walter the butcher. The bowler. The Chicago cubs fan. Walter was ninety and had the untrustable, falling apart body of a ninety year old. I guided him by the arm as Mike strode ahead and Walter pushed his body forward slowly with a cane. He was being washed in nostalgia and trauma from when he grew up in Darmstadt, eventually being forced to escape to the States and leave his mother there, with a faint promise to send for her, a promise unfulfilled as she perished in the camps soon after he left. Michael had three children back in Chicago and I had none. Instead I chose to leave the US and return to Deutschland to live, with maybe even some slight percentage of the decision restitution for what happened to my family. “How is it to be here, grandpa?” I asked as we walked, as the pigeons flew out of the way along the path. “What?” Walter answered, as he was hard of hearing, as he had been for years, a thing he sometimes used as an excuse to tune out his wife, but perhaps, I thought, a lot of his attention was on his experience returning to Deutschland, and he just wasn’t listening to me. “How is it being back here, grandpa?” I repeated, this time leaning closer to his ear as we walked. “You and MIchael have grown plump,” he said, a twisting, gravel of a German accent still lacing his voice. I smiled and watched MIchael bound ahead like a young deer, excited to be adventuring outside of his homeland.

title: I Spent So Many Years Writing
content:
moon poems, now it is time
for the sun to rise
through the words
like rays cutting through streaks
of clouds on the horizon.

like breathing life into a poem
instead of removing death from it.
like shaping the clay of a beautiful statue
instead of chipping away at the absence of it.

this year is the year of the snake.
this year is the year of the sun poem.
this year I will find a new place to live
where light comes beaming through the window

in the morning or the evening,
where I can sit drinking coffee and write
and write and write and write
and be filled up with the rays of the sun,
with love that has been absent for so long.

title: Before the Sunrise
content:
the gray haze of the horizon
allows a streak or two of pink light
through the clouds.

this stabbing feeling I have in my heart
is just jealousy’s rust blade
stuck like an unforgettable Disney romance
planted as a wee child
too young to know poison from a flower.

I look out across the dull blue water
between two parallel skyscrapers
each outlined with three red lights
towering like lighthouses
looking for that red glowing ball
waiting for it to rise like your eyes
and look at me with warming love.

but my body tingles with this fear
that there will never be light again
that the darkness of the morning will just continue
endlessly as jealousy paints the clouds dull
making me fantasize about you
running off with these hotter monsters
as if the sun would suddenly wake up
one day and run off to a distant solar system
that could make it explode with ecstacy
to an extent I doubt I can provide.

the red unblinking lights 
on the towers suddenly change
to flashing white lights 
and that is a reminder
to me that I’m being silly
that the sun is coming up
that you will continue to love me
like you do every morning
that even if you do go off and explode
that you will come back 
because this is the place 
where you feel at home.

title: The Dogs of Tenerife
content:
How can we be such racist,
sexist, fascist assholes
destroying the Earth carelessly
year after year
when a dog is a dog
no matter the country?

It’s just these dogs here
respond to siéntate, cállate,
same as the children 
and dogs of the US 
respond to sit, speak, 
just the same
as dogs of Berlin
respond to komm, setz sich,
just the same
as all the other dogs 
of the world.

We just make up 
all these insane differences
to, what, hate each other more?

Because, why, we don’t have enough
to worry about 
feeding ourselves,
seeking shelter, trying, 
just trying not to die every day?

It just doesn’t make any
doggone sense.

title: I Played Padel Today. With a Nazi. 🙄 At Least I Kicked His Ass?
content:
I didn’t even notice he was Nazi 
like until the end when we got up close 
and he wouldn’t even look me in the eye–
this Jew who made him sweat 
on the court. 

I didn’t even know he was a Nazi 
until after the match, this shaved headed, 
tattoo-arm-sleeve mother fucker 
who invited the other guy to take 
a beer after the match but not me, 
because he had it written in his profile: 
JUGADOR A DERECHAS.

"I am a player to the right”, he tells me,
which just gave me the total fucking creeps 
(perhaps he meant human rights?),
and I doubt myself for a second, but no, 
when I scoped the profiles’ of the friends 
he usually played with they each had SS 
in their name, which, goddamnit, 
if that isn’t a clear enough sign 
then just spank me silly 
with a padel racquet until I’m dead. 

How often does he get beat 
by a guy from the very group he hates 
enough to make it an identity? Not enough 
is the answer but it’s not like I’m any different--
him in his black and red bubble of hate
and me in my blue bubble of poetry. 

We’re all so isolated these days, 
the only war we’ll ever fight is on the internet 
blocking each other on a stupid app 
meant to connect padel players. 

What a bunch of chicken shit, 
digital lizards we all are, insulated 
from each other enough to inflame 
our idiotic beliefs without checks, 
without legitimate discourse, drawing 
our guns when fear whispers 
dirty things in our ears about legacy, 
murder as a means of self-preservation, 
the terrible, terrifying value 
in hating the self.

content:

aliens playing hooky from space school

flare your nostrils if that’s what it takes
          the truth is I can live
without you but I can’t live without
breathing and that is the difference
between when I say I love bacon
and I love you and I love water

title: Bored With Life? Call Andy.
content:
too lazy to capitalize 
the first letter of the first word of each sentence? 
call someone else. 
you want to be a poet you have to write. 
you have to write and write and write. 
you have to write when you are stoned. 
you have to write meaningless drivel. 
you just have to make more poems 
and more stories and more dead raincoats 
and put them in boxes and stuff the boxes 
and shove them in the attic. you have to
really fill that fucker up. don’t go up there. 
don’t look in those boxes. just write and write. 
don’t read any of it. write. keep writing. a bit more. 
even more. have some coffee. have some whiskey. 
write on the plane. in the park. at the zoo. 
in a restaurant. alone. together with a friend. 
just pull out your notebook and write stuff down. 
but don’t read any of it. not yet. wait until later. 
that is the trick to being a good writer. 
write. and then pack it up. write and pack it up 
and forget about it. and then later when you return to look 
at the bullshit you had to write before you write how you do now. 
you should not recognise the words. in the attic. 
and the stuff that you read when you return 
to look at what you are writing now. you should not remember 
having written it. you should have no sense 
of who the person was who wrote this shit. maybe 
it will trigger a smell memory. or a sense or a vision 
of a past time with someone. or a place. with you. 
with me. love? is it? is it horrible? does it ring any bells? of course. 
it is you but it is not you. so then 
find the essence in the pages. and twist it into a story. 
polish it into something cloudy but with a shape 
with the light shining through a little more. 
because you forgot the ego of the time when you wrote it. 
because now you can see past and through and around the dead stuff. 
because now your pen has sprouted and branched and bloomed. 
to where that juicy organic pulp is. down there rotting like a mushroom 
under a pile of wet leaves. waiting to be found. and fried 
with butter and garlic for breakfast. while 
you are writing. with coffee stains on the pages.

title: The Smell of the Street
content:
The smell of the street as I walk
out and down the promenade
in Santa Cruz de Tenerife
brings me back fifteen years ago
to when I lived in Aranjuez–
rubbish mixed with dry desert air
mixed with fruit mixed with the odors 
of Spanish people mixed with car exhaust
mixed with a hint of crusted dog shit.

That doesn’t even begin to capture
the smell that was so foreign to me,
a young buck fresh out of Minneapolis,
when I first arrived in Spain, that took
quite some getting used to, that
I really could not forget after a while,
that now feels familiar like taking a whiff
of an ex’s sweater or cracking the lid
of a fresh can of smoked oysters in olive oil
because that’s what my dad used to eat.

You try sitting down and describing 
a smell from the streets of your hometown.
It will take all of your words
just to capture the tail of the aroma
that flooded your nine year old nostrils
every day without even one conscious
thought about it.

title: Poem
content:
Walking through the park, I am 
compelled at least once per journey
to stray off the designated path, 
sodding my feet in wet mud, 
breaking blades of grass, taking small steps 
into the wild– a faint rejection to being 
told where to go, where not to be; 
this is starting to feel like life: 
a constant navigation 
through boxes, the desire to dip 
toes outside their walls.

Upon rusty, wet leaves, 
taking off my face, I unwrap 
in the limelight of the big show, 
let out a small, barbed yawp, 
unheard beyond bud stuffed ears, 
into a clouding blue sky.

title: Silver Leaves of the Moon
content:
Two black dogs howl at the moon
as we walk through the forest
looking for our selves, as moonlight 
strobes between trunks,
as pine needles crunch under our feet
and even though it is night it is not dark
as we are out with silver lanterns
as we walk from this tower to that one
as crustaceans crawl from memories
dwelling in the depths of once powerful wells.

Do you see in the pitch black
like the blind? Do you leave the door open
to hear the music of the countryside
even when you want to stay at home 
all Saturday night? Do you accept
the violent ripcurls of the tides that kiss 
the black sand beach of El Bollullo?

These are the questions lacing the howls 
of two black dogs, exalting their companion,
Hecate, as they shake off waters
of the subconscious from their coat.

title: We are Waiting for another Singer of the Year
content:
to make our hearts cry. Nothing much at all
has changed in a hundred years. Fascism 
on the rise. Singers and poets still an afterthought,
a half a glance worth in the attention economy, 
only fractions of cents per tear jerk 
stream. Dust bowl plain, rumored weapon

Hands of the wealthy play us stringed data 
holes like poker chips, still have private parties 
weaving in the Catskills, a thin, blinding blanket

her, in the dull brown amber glow of a spanking 
brand new Amazon tower, as the busy delivery

in the background of all of our 
consciousnesses?

title: Hanging on Just by a Thread
content:

when you will fall
into the cocoon
of my arms.

title: Diary of a Programmer 06
content:
Who would have thought twenty five years
ago we would all have written a novel
with our thumbs by the end of life, 
publishing it in bursts of 100 characters?

I imagine the micro manuscripts
are grasped by the claws
of invisible digital pigeons surfing
electronic waves and delivered
to the publishing houses
of lovers, parents, friends,
or dumped hopelessly/fully
into the ether of a bottomless
publishing machine hole 
that we have named social media.

This is the thought I have
as I scribble idiotic poetry
into a small, light teal Leuchtturm1917 
notebook on the S-Bahn, as I watch
the eyes of everyone staring
at their small black rectangle,
their two fattest and shortest digits
jiggling back and forth,
as I take a mental snapshot
and place an old Sunday paper cartoon
section filter on it, placing parentheses
around the thumbs of everyone to
denote the rapidity of movement.

he could tell and before long we parted 
          ways

title: Another Lonely Indian Boy from Calcutta
content:
I always felt like an Indian boy 
from Calcutta banging on the tabla 
reading from right to left eating rice and dahl 
               night after night trying 
like a bad monk to transcend eating pizza only 
when my mother was teaching new parents 
to push consciousness freshly wrapped in skin 
through a vaginal hole like a universal crime 
                                             and I will confess 
that Berlin has done nothing outside
of serve as a reminder how much I am not 
the compilation of myths that I concretized 
while peering out of the eyes of a ten year old 
Iowan
               I ask the kid 
on the S-Bahn if it gets lonely and what 
he does besides sport and work but instead 
he tells me he has given up  
                                                       dating 
as there’s no room in Deutschland for others
like him and I know exactly what he means 
                              living in Buckow 
of all the lonely places 
as everyone on the train averts their eyes 
as they all pretend not to see him on the street
as if they were born with the inside of their eyelids
                                             painted white
as I remember why I was forced to take a vow 
                                                            of silence
surrounded by those who prefer not to talk
to me but instead to another lonely Indian boy
from Calcutta

title: TV On Neptune
content:
I’ve come to where they wander 
to, with disregard for Neptune, 
                        stoned and exiled 
from the sea to Berlin, where 
they follow their small black rectangles 
to the place of Alexander, opting to snap, 
not like a twig or a turtle or the ego 
but, a pic. They tilt the lens high up 
towards the sky attempting to capture 
and freeze patchy clouds backing a giant 
glass ball spiked on a spire, broadcasting out 
sans discrimination, rays of television. 

I’ve come to sit on a bench, eat delicious 
Bánh Mi, number 59, pulled 
from a pig, watch stone seals spit 
water high as they can but always fail 
to touch the veins of the verdigris god. 
                     But yeah, sure, call me
the odd man out with pen and paper 
because no one writes any more
obviously in public.

content:

on breathing we stroked along you with your mezzo-soprano lungs

always out of the water like turtles in the awkward silence of those 
who don’t know how to be together quietly yet on the other side

of dates a certain ambivalence to the results there that comes 
with age with moonlight reflecting off the windows of the heart as we run

title: Heat Break
content:
The coconut oil in the glass jar 
is wet as soup 
so we go swimming 
in the poison ivy 
of our relationship 
that suddenly caught fire, 
trying to cool off 
the recent explosions. 
As we slowly burn, 
we try to thwart 
the inevitable end 
in ash, looking 
for a fire escape, 
hoping each word thrown 
is laced enough with love, 
with best intentions, to bring us 
together amidst the solar eclipse 
of collapse. We cast
rejoinders but the walls, 
once holding us up, together, melt, 
until we can see through them, 
their structure disappearing 
beneath us, around us, within us
until only a ghost of us is left, 
a hologram of an ideal pair. Seared 
into the museum of our memories, 
in the hall of exes, each vacant ember
remains like smoked potential, 
contains an unborn phoenix,
on display for future 
investigations of arson.

title: Unbirdled Honesty

title: If the Lasso of Wonder Woman Was Forcing You to Tell the Truth
content:
You hang from the threads 
of a backwards dog, tongue wagging, dripping 
with the sweat of a horny pig, fearing
a sloppy drop, shaggy knot, 
long term nerve damage 
in the veins of the spirit,
that never comes.

Forty two years in, you finally surrender 
to the snakes, constricting
around your ankles, wrists, chest, thighs, waist,

like nooses tied with freedom, with love, 
as if the lasso of Wonder Woman was forcing you 
to tell the truth, expose the heart you buried 

as a child– a heart, like an empty sailboat, 
given away too soon.
The cords, mooring it 
to the dock, cut, casting it 
into exile, a wandering ghost 
lost in the turbid waves 
of the stormy sea. 

If only someone would have taught you
how to bind your body with love,
so that you could now feel safe, 
slotted in the harbour, protected 
from constant and battering winds, 
the echoes of trauma.

But no. Instead, you can only get close
to this feeling of true rest, with the help 
of a backwards dog licking 
your wounds with his ropes,
listening to your tears,
tuning in and out of the channels
of your pain.

title: Strawberry Moon
content:
After walking for three days, my knees 
accidentally bumped the knees of the kissy couple 
sitting across from me. I peered out the window 
of the train at the landscapes of my childhood—
fields of wheat, flatness, sprouting wind farms—
on the way from Eberswalde to Berlin. 

I closed my eyes, swam naked 
under a full strawberry moon, with a horse 
tarot lady who I have yet to meet.

There are questions I ask myself
as I walk. Ever see a duck hop 
like a rabbit? Ever catch a hermit silhouetting 
as an emperor or a fool? Ever hear a sound 
that sounds like another sound? 

There are answers as well. A gunshot branch 
snapping from the top of a pine tree. The grunt
when it hits the ground. A creaky door 
in the woods. The red, white, and
yellow wildflowers tickled by the wind
outlining a farmer's crop.

In the evenings I constructed a tent 
of ideas, when I allowed my mind
to fill in, as I used to before the age
of black squared obsession,
only to be torn down again
in the morning.

In the night, from somewhere, a voice, 
like a siren weaving a spell through the trees, 
sang– I want to be with you 
everywhere– so loud that I couldn’t sleep 
and my head rang with the laughter 
that should always come after pain. 

This time, once again, I followed the yellow shells, 
backlit by a blue ocean, and I passed three nests
built for storks but I only saw one stork 
and her black beaked babies. Each nest
 
looked like a tower from the windows 
of which I imagined we had just fallen. 
As we were falling towards the ground, 
we uselessly flapped our arms 
like hummingbird wings, fast as we could, 
with panicky sadness, but then we spotted 
the setting sun.

We froze in the air, as we forgot about time 
and savored the view of the burning orange sky, 
together, just moments before death.

title: A Perpetual Burgeoning of Realisations of Absurdity
content:
Berlin is a collection of former strangers 
to their own homeland, current foreigners 
in a strange land, outsiders who never felt at home
 
at home, anywhere, with anyone, who can’t dance 
but dance, who hop from techno ballet
to being strung up in a S-Bahn opera 
like a red light, dangling upside down 
from the feet, who were running away
from or towards the flickering lights 
of an Aldi, that market of odds and ends 
where people panic, prepare for robot 

armed cashiers, where they organize
with others alike, with whom they can relate, 
in the not being able to relate, at 3am
outside a late shop, this ship 
and that ship, passing by, floating 
down the Spree in a fog, connecting 

through disconnection, a kinship of strangers 
to the self, to the body, to the spirit, fleshy 
vehicles driving on a dirty terrain, 
peering out through slits, with feet firmly planted 
on the moon, somewhere 
far away, like aliens, who parachute 

down into the illusion of life, wear it
as a costume, to the office, 
where a backwards dog 
who of course also moonlights 
as a deejay, types away blindly, blissfully
at the desk of western teleology 
until the weekend comes, and they just fall
into another hole, another punch 
of the fifty two in the story of the year,

when, without gravity, they disappear, 
forget the weight they were carrying
in a backpack, a shell, that was carefully selected 
by the owner, that suits the owner’s shape, 
that is functional, that is lightweight, that is extendable,
that is compared and contrasted, while waiting
for a very late locomotive, on a platform 
in Leipzig, and picked up and slung
over the shoulders, as a test of camaraderie, 
by every member of the community
of outlanders.

title: Moon Over the Tenth Day of Walking
content: for the Starship Edwardprise Now you have arrived in Santiago after a long walk down a dirt path, down a pine needle path, down a path of stone, banana leaves, concrete, sand, pebbles, under bridges, through tunnels, over hills, between towns, next to lakes, meadows of cows, pastures of horses, olive tree groves, growling dogs, homeless cats, in and around forests of tall, thin white trees, of thick trunked, plush dark green canopies, with light glittering through, of golden fields brushed by wind. Now you can finally stop moving your feet and disregard the Spanish sun. Eventually, you will go back to pretending that time matters, that there is past and future, that there is money to be made. But for now forget about limping along with burnt arms, hobbling past houses made of stone, built by hand, as the surrounding beauty eclipsed the suffering of your body. Now you know, on this path, youth becomes old, with each step, and the old become new, with their accumulated wisdom of learned pacing. But forget all that now, as the final day closes. Take a breath and recognise how much ground was covered in just ten days, half a country, and recognise the subtle corner of this complicated life that became just a little easier, and just a little harder in ways you couldn’t have expected, and do not judge anything but come back to your old self slowly, with just a little more of your well filled up, a hidden font for some time later, to draw upon when things become hairy again.

title: A Meditation on Resilience
content:
A scrape on a stone, permanent 
as it seems, short as it is 
next to the length of the light 
of the cosmos, lasts 
just a tad longer than a tattoo.

While a stick drawn 
through desert sand, pushes 
up grain, forms little walls 
into the sides of a tiny grand 
canyon for honey pot ants, 
lasts a long while until 

wind brushes the empty space 
with more sand, paves the surface, fills it 
in with time, turns it into some forgotten 
destination, long after the end 
of tourism, but way before the sun 
blips out, and before the ink dries up.

Eventually, rain finally 
falls, pools, rivers its way
downhill, which, to a seagull’s eye, 
looks like lightning patterned veins 

extending down from the crest 
of a dune, small streams of clear blue 
blood returning to the heart, pushed
and pulled by gravity, 
compelled to the salted sea 
on which a boat, black speck, 
jibes downwind, leaving 
a wake disappearing 
behind it 
without a second 
thought.

title: Share
content:
I snap a pic of a pony 
tailed millennial Berlin 
father, wearing a tee shirt 
saying SPACELORD MOTHERFUCKER, 
walking his helmeted, rollerblading seven 
year old daughter to the Kita 
am Treptower Park, a child 

of the recently fucked 
cosmos. A ubiquitous task 
these days, too easy. 

On the balcony I make the colors 
pop when suddenly I am proud– this 
has come to mean something. 
I’ve captured the city 
forever. A short 
life. A longer one. Who should want 
to partake? The question begs 
like a blind artist. Who else 
will get it? Who will look like I do 
and grin? I shrug the feeling off. 
There is no one else 

here. I have attempted
a sort of refrain 
from mirrored applications, 
for years now, cutting myself 
off from manicured windows 
into networks of those 
I once knew, know now, will never 
know. It’s just a feeling though 

that preciousness 
has been sucked 
clean 
out of solitude.

title: She Gave Me the Kiss
content:
She gave me the kiss
of death on the forehead,
just between the eyes,
and thus

I can see everything
and nothing
as I walk
through life
with three swords
stuck through my heart.

Each time I pull one
out, to protect myself,
blood gushes
to the ground
until it’s too much
to bear and I must slide
the sword back in
until I am swathed, safe, 
merely suffering.

As if anyone could ever plug 
such a deep hole,
dressed up as a cup,
handed down the bloodlines
through rites 
of love, perverted.

title: Moon Over Norway Lake
content:
When we turned off the lights 
in the lake house, our reflections 
in the windows disappeared.
Through the panes, we watched
the full moon cast down a spotlight 
onto the solid surface of the lake.

Where once I had seen myself, now 
I was forgotten in the stillness 
of winter. When I lay down in bed 
I felt my body floating up 
into the ice-fishing house 
of dreams. 

A ceramic owl stared 
back at us from the deck,
vainly looking for a coffee grinder, 
considering the perils and pleasures 
of money, the different shades 
of muppets, the absurdity
of its own frozenness.

The moon watched me 
as I slept. She told me so 
in the morning: I talked more 
than usual in my sleep,
about a cyclops, laughing,
as it slowly died,
its eyebrow crystallizing 
in the arctic breeze, 
while puffs of heated breath 
fogged up its monocle. 

I awoke to a pink banner 
highlighting the sky
above the treetops 
circling Norway Lake.

title: Just Say Aah
content:
“What do you do?” she asks.
“I’m a dentist,” he says
and she purses her lips 
and opens them (to speak) 
but it doesn’t matter:

he dives into her mouth anyway 
through the gates of teeth 
and presses his metal scalpel against her 
tongue with the gentleness of a cold 
cock while carelessly humming 
 a bad Wagner lick

and she convinces herself 
she must really need surgery, 
having no insurance and all
of a trauma free incident–
an expensive choice 
in the post freedom from, freedom to 
wisdom teeth era.

“What do you do?” he asks
and she bites down (hard), 
letting her career untether and float 
like a hot air balloon into the ether 
that is putting her to sleep because, 
she thinks, it still feels like 1950, 
and her apron strings are untied 
and what better way to say unemployed 
influencer than housewife, 

as the desire to kiss the motherfucker 
on the mouth (with a punch) 
bubbles up from her belly 
like a sadist about to boil
and comes barfing out 
onto the cock’s 
operating table 
and all over his reputation 
for being a nice guy. 

“Shall we order a bottle 
of wine, then?” he asks.

title: Tarry
content:
Somewhere between a rocket 
to the moon and falling 
asleep in a rocking chair 
a caterpillar is building a cocoon 
from which it will never emerge,
a fledgling refuses 
to be pushed
from the brim of a nest,
a leap frog’s legs lock
in fear of leaving the lily
on which it has stead.

Somewhere between the course 
of a lifetime and the blink 
of an eye, a butt 
has become indistinguishable 
from a sofa cushion, 
the mantled fireplace 
of a suburban townhouse 
has begun to look like prison bars, 
the once invigorating idea 
of flirting with flies 
at the bar has become 
a swattable nuisance.

Shouldn’t it just be easy to cut 
the strings from which you hang?

Somewhere between a noose
and the life saving lines
dangling from an IV bag,
something holds us back,
holds us up, 
holds us
accountable.

title: The Young, the Aged, the Big Show
content:
(To have the disposition)
of those who measure coolness 
by how long one can make it 
at the party: the hippest, the last up 
to see the sun rise, the ones 
who make out 
at bacon mornings 
to an orchestra of coffee 
and eggs with stars 
still in their eyes and nose 
and stars still
on their tongues. 

And, of those who measure time 
out at a party often, 
by how much one can take 
of the party, by how much party 
one is able to stand and dance 
on sore feet–
until the sun rises?–
before the call to bed (ridden, 
like a locomotive) is too loud 
to ignore, the whistle: damn-
these people are true 
artists, trendsetters, really open 
books– I just can’t. 

Later I choke myself 
off, wile out alone at home (sifting 
the night for poems), prescriptively 
feeding the darkness 
on the edge of town, an outlier 
to the headliners 
of the real, big show.
