title: Moon Poem #156
content:
Look at her up in the sky, sitting 
there, naturally, in her moon chamber, 
orbiting, typing away at her cosmic typewriter. 

Watch as her fingers dance 
across the keys as if she were a pianist 
playing a moonlit sonata. As she pauses 
to think, she draws in a breath, pulling 
from a pipe branching from her 
lips, the bowl packed to the brim 
with kismet, with hot coals 
of stardust glowing red 
like young stars. 

She lets smoke escape her lips,
a shroud of clouds dances 
around her like the rings of Saturn. 

Thwack thwack go the keys. Ding goes the bell 
as the carriage runs out at the end 
of each tide. She logs all the events 
of history, as usual, all the stories 
of time. She has both witnessed all of it 
and been a part of it all. She writes 

in her cosmic journal: tales 
of evolution, excitement, genocide, 
sorrow; she has seen the most terrible 
things and the most beautiful 
things. Is there any difference? she asks
herself as she pulls back 
the carriage and lets the tide flow 
out. Her mind empties 

and begins to fill up again- pooling
and swirling in the great cosmic bird bath- 
her fingers type the tide 
in, smooching the sand just a little 

more every minute. The blood red
clouds begin to drip, the mountains echo 
with howls. A lonely fool, bumbles along 
innocently, stumbles across the stones 
at the base of a tower. A very high 
priestess performs magical rituals 
at the top of the very same tower.

at the top of the very same tower.

content:
The piss yellow

skin,

on the other side of a teenage blackout. I finger

to place black electrical tape over the eyes 
and mouth in exes, to slip this fleshy sack of skin
and surf the silvery skies, on waves of cocaine clouds, 

until

but a dead doll.

title: Untitled Poem (One Must Sit in the Darkness)
content:
To distract myself from the noise of a German 
crowd at the next table, I conjure a blue horse 
with the head of Leonora Carrington. 

She slips
into a bodice
made of shards of mirrors
and weaves 
in and out of the trees 
of a French forest.

She does a terrible job 
evading Nazis, at dusk
her blue and shimmering figure
too easy to spot between the dark 
grey and brown trunks.

Murakami tells me
that it will rain tomorrow 
if a polar bear eats 
the stars tonight, and he is not wrong,
as it happens, the moon, closing 
in on full, is blurred 
by a thin veil of clouds, 
like an opaque sheath
for a cratered oatmeal cookie. 

It only makes me love her 
more, knowing she will escape, 
as the hard rains fall
and wash the paint
from her saddled back,
as she disappears
into insanity without Max.

I think she is following me 
around (or am I following her?), 
but it is too late in life to know 
any more, without being certain 

whether, eventually (and this too 
is stolen from Murakami), the jumble 
of knots will loose;
be patient, she neighs in echoes, unravelling 
takes time, she whinnies in straits–
one must sit 

in the darkness long enough 
for the eyes to adjust, to see 
a way out, to carve a door,
into the black canvas
of the mind.

title: Sun Over a Robinson 44II Raven
content:
He convinces a red teardrop to tilt
and ascend into the sky
with just two blades circling overhead
like a halo and a tail
to generate sideways
thrust.

Below, beyond the Strip, 
pools of blue punctuate the backyards
across vast, beige desert sprawl
as we chop through Railroad Pass
Highway 93 towards the dam.

He has not exactly grown wings
but is birdlike nonetheless–
soaring through the air,
always vigilant, aware

one small miscalculation,
one hasty jolt of the stick,
could turn the ground,
not so far beneath us,
into a predator.

I swallow nervously, eat
my microphone, 
let excited spurts fly, 
as bubbles of anti-gravity rise 
up from my stomach, and escape 
like belches. 

Only awe and pride, I hope, 
are advertised on my face
as I settle into trusting my brother,
pilot of the Raven, a boy 
I once saw fall out of a tree.

title: An Uninterrupted Weekend
content:
Suddenly, the birds stop 
by like neighbours 
with frozen beards, 
huffing puffs of breath 
into the arctic air on the porch.  
They flit about,
holding a hot blueberry 
pie, steam rising from the star 
cut crusted top. 
I walk to the door, 
reach for the handle 
and then decide, no, 
no visitors right now, 
not this weekend, 
not while the top of the lake 
is frozen and the coffee 
is about to finish steeping.  

Sometimes silence is louder 
in the winter, louder than in the city, 
louder than the birds 
of my mind, who I keep 
ushering South.  

Sometimes silence is so loud 
it makes my teeth hurt.

title: Moon Over Divorce
content:
Two souls- 
the yolks of the human body- 
who began by walking 
side by side down city streets 
through all four seasons, 
formed a bond, were bound, 
like two sunny side up eggs 
frying in the pan: they hardened, 
fused together; 

the moon watched them, winking 
shut and unwinking open, the two 
souls, pooling their edges, forgetting 
their boundaries, sizzling on the black 
cast iron Earth, and sprinkled in emotion: 
a dash of joy, a spoonful of sorrow.

But, eventually, as we all know, 
it is time to eat 
and the giant spatula of time 
sets itself down, severs these two 
souls, sometimes before they are ready, 
and maroons them, separately, 
each on their own island 
of lox and caraway rye.

title: Desert Sun Over Las Vegas #1
content:
After all-u-can-eat Sushi we drive 
back, through traffic light after traffic 
light, stripmall after stripmall, neighbourhood 
after neighbourhood, and I can’t tell 

anything apart, each wall, each roof, each column 
and terrace the same terra cotta material, the same 
desert architecture, less than thirty years old, built 
to absorb and decrease the desert heat and yet 

each story inside, I want to say, I really, painfully 
want to say, must be completely different in terms 
of narrative, plot, character, conflict, and resolution. 
But after a quick, maiden run (for me) to Costco 

earlier in the day with my brother, man, 
I just don’t know. In the evening hour, in the dead, 
black heat of the Las Vegas night, we sit 
on the back patio, hashing and rehashing 

my childhood, sipping non-alcoholic beer, laughing, 
thinking, processing, farting, laying down bridges 
and pulling them up again, somehow connecting 
through the emotional fog of my father. 

Before we get up to go inside, my brother’s girlfriend 
flicks on a blacklight torch, a tool I didn’t know we needed,
scans for scorpions, a threat I didn’t know existed.

I place my socked feet on the wooden, Walmart coffee table,
slide my hand inside a giant bag of Himalayan salted crisps
and secretly hope to feel the shelled and spidery legs of a scorpion.

title: The Waves, The Wind, The Warblers
content:
In the small town of Lido, on the northern shore of Spain 
I fell asleep and woke up in a tiny albergue on the cliffs 
with the sound of waves crashing into the black, spongy rocks 
far below, my body exhausted from only walking, walking 
for weeks, walking, walking.

And, in a field, also in the north of Spain, I cannot say where, 
amidst grass as high as my knees, I lay down during the afternoon 
siesta, fell asleep, and woke up to the heat of the Summer cut 
by waving, leafy branches above me, with the sound of the wind 
whooshing through the forest, tickling my ears, soothing my sunburnt skin.

And now, when I awake in my own bed it is to the chirp 
of a sparrow or a titmouse on the balcony, perched 
upon a branch in the bundle we have assembled for them, announcing 
its arrival, departure, exalting the day, informing the others 
of food, its tiny round head rotating 

like the domed top of an observatory to the stars.
I want to recognise these three offerings 
of nature: may I remember that not all of us 
are privileged enough to know them, to have 
the space to hear them. Even I, in moments 

of darkness, under the mechanical chuff of the Locomotive, 
forget these three beautiful sounds: 
the waves, the wind, and the warblers.

content:
I stroll through Brooklyn dripping 
with sweat like a lizard baking 
in the summer heat, while a titmouse lands 
on my shoulder, whispering 
in my ear, flies off, leaves a rose

of passion, and one spicy, American 
sun cooked tomato- the manager 
of the party- who left a sad olive behind,

heels, merely wishing for a dry toe 
sock up their arse.

of Cancer. I drag smoke 
from my lips, push and pull

as we do the dance 
of relationship, with moonlight 
guiding our kisses and words 
attempting to bridge our fears, desires, 
never quite as successful as a roll 
in the bed after the tide comes in. 

What can we do but ride 
the waves? What can we do 
but let the semen tanks fill up
and then jizz all over 
the rooftops of NYC?

content:

on over the loud speaker.

title: Sun Over a Grilled Chicken Wrap
content:
Tuna fish ice cream 
is advertised (in German), 
with hipster panache, 
in brazen, mint green 
typeface on the wall 
across the food court 

while I stuff my face 
at a table in the mall, 
without a plate, 
clutching my wrap as if it were a handlebar, 
self-consciously 
leafing through the faces 
in dating apps, as if they were different 
sizes and colours of tee shirts 
in a clothes rack at H and M. 
Is anyone watching 
me scroll? I think and I turn 
my phone into a black mirror, 
uncap my pen, and write 
about tuna fish ice cream, pausing 
to stare at the upside down plants 
hanging from the ceiling, each one 
a jarring work of art, in mockery 
of nature.

title: They Think, Coo, They Say, Nothing
content:
I always forget how 
when stepping off the pier, as soon as my feet 
touch the sand, there is a tremendous shift 
in speed, like stepping off the moving walkway 
at the airport. Time slows down, the body 
feels heavier, takes more effort to heave forward. 

In that instant I want to stop 
and sink, listen to the water lap, 
watch the blades of distant wind 
turbines turn; watch the grass, the grass 
blowing on the dunes of the shore. 

Isn’t it just like after the end 
of a relationship? Everything is harder, 
life feels heavier, the heart weighs more 
than the body, the head, in the clouds, just something 
to drag around. 

I always forget and as I feel my feet 
sink into to the sand, I know I must keep 
going if I want to dip a toe 
in the waters of Øresund. 

I notice the beach salted 
with tiny white shells and even 
the differently colored seagulls 
seem depressed, just standing by the water's edge 
on their feet, staring out to sea, flightless. 

What is even the point 
anymore, they think, 
coo, they say, nothing 
is as easy as it used to be.

with tiny white shells and even 
the differently colored seagulls 
seem depressed, just standing by the water's edge 
on their feet, staring out to sea, flightless. 

What is even the point 
anymore, they think, 
coo, they say, nothing

title: Months and Months of Moons and then a Sun
content:
In the evenings there was darkness and in the mornings 
there wasn’t, so we worked as if it were normal 
and made love in the alcoves of the afternoon 
in the homes we constructed as if we were birds 

building a nest. Seven hundred years later, we thought, 
all this will not matter, but it did not expire 
our hopes, no, it did not make us eat less 
turkey or stuff our sack-like bodies into the car 

less or buy a different kind of peanut butter 
but actually increased the amount of hugs we gave 
and the amount of scarves we knitted 
and we even started playing records again. 

It isn’t such a feat, we believed, to build skyscrapers 
but to walk on two legs and to talk with a tongue 
and to record music and to carry it 
with us like money or to see with the eyes of a pen 

travelling in the pocket of a famous writer, yes, 
yes, we laughed, these are the redefinitions 
that should plaster the halls which separate the past 
from the future, this is the graffiti that should be inked 

upon the heart, such are the missing advertisements
written by the PR department of heaven.
